albumData.title: 140918 Stacking blocks not over base
albumData.description: I didn't think you could do it, turns out you can.

media.description:
I didn't think you could stack identical blocks out over the extents of the base without having more blocks on top to secure them.  It turns out you can. Hmm.
(The bottom two don't need to be upside down either)

comments.author: John R. Sippy
comments.comment: Well, your first 3 stacked blocks are supported on ~90% of their length, and your 4th looks to be supported on ~75%. I would think you could stack using the 90% method for quite a free more iterations before encountering instabilities.

comments.author: Scott Williamson
comments.comment:
Actually, mathematically there is no limit to how far you can stack blocks out over the base.  Practical limitations are discovered soon.

(http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/mathematics/18-01sc-single-variable-calculus-fall-2010/unit-5-exploring-the-infinite/part-b-taylor-series/session-96-stacking-blocks/MIT18_01SCF10_Ses96b.pdf)

comments.comment: Now if you just made another copy, reversed and abutting, you could make some sort of "arched" opening.  It wouldn't be very stable though unless you added some sort of object in the middle, at the top, to hold everything together.  I imagine such a piece would be rather "key".  :P
